intro: Tetraena mandavillei, commonly known as the Mandaville tetraena, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean island of Hispaniola. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its woody structure and showy flowers. The plant produces small, five-petaled flowers that are typically white or pale pink, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in tropical climates and is often found in dry, rocky habitats. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
